story:
I, one of the overwhelmed, wandering college grads, and one of the extremely underpaid, marginalized educators in this society, am raising money to produce stickers & t-shirts with my signature "artivist" design. My main goal is to change mainstream culture, or at the very least to respond to it with a big, fat "Fuck You". 

Here is my story.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

My name is Eryn Kimura and I am a 5th generation San Franciscan and 5th generation Chinese-/Japanese-American, respectively. I am a narrator, creator, and educator/facilitator, and a proud polycultural product of the San Francisco public school system.  

Growing up with white best friends that knew more Cantonese and Mandarin than me, I had no idea I was Asian until I left the Baytastic bubble to UC Santa Barbara, circa 2009. It was here in college that I experienced my first microagression - a social exchange in which a member of the dominant culture belittles or alienates one of a marginalized group. "You're really good at math, huh?" 

The trend continued thereafter. 

At UCSB, I found myself living on the lively 6600 block of Del Playa - the party street of the college town, alongside the breathtaking Pacific Ocean. The echoing sound of rolling red cups in the wind, the invasive presence of dirty dub step prying into your eardrums at 4 AM...this was where I lived. This is also where I came across a pretty white boy, who later texted me with "What are you up to, my oriental fantasy?" Mortified, I wanted to throw up in my mouth and peel off my skin, as if it was a spandex ninja suit, except a ninja suit that spelled: "Hi! I'm a demure, powerless, sexual object that will give you a massage for breakfast, lunch, and dinner! PLEASE call me a goofy, politically incorrect name that usually is paired with rugs or Panda Express dishes!" Oh hell no. 

From then on, it was like my ancestors and the collective universe wanted me to feel such discomfort, extreme anger, and disgust at least once a week with such infuriating interactions. 

"Do you give massages?" 

"You blind, stupid, Asian slut...love, skinhead." 

"...there's that Asian persuasion..." 

"...you fuckin' chink." 

"...I'm sorry, but I have been looking at your cleavage."

Obviously, I had to deal with the subsequent anger constructively. I ended up double majoring in Asian-American Studies and Psychology, with a minor in Black Studies. It was in my ethnic studies courses that I finally felt empowered to be a womxn of color, more specifically an Asian-American womxn. Through such academic rigor, I found myself armed with literary weapons forged by fellow brilliant and resilient creators and paradigm-shifters, such as bell hooks, Grace Lee Boggs, and Angela Davis. My personal wealth of witty sass hit an all time high. 

Graduating from UCSB in 2013, I returned to the motherland: San Francisco. However, yet again my ancestors in the clouds decided to challenge me. One month into post-college life, I ended up filing a sexual harassment claim against a patriarchal 63-year old executive director of an environmental justice nonprofit I began interning for. 

 Salting the wound that had been open for more than a century, I was yet again,  "orientalized". Based on my phenotypic similarity to the exotic, demure Japanese Madam Butterfly - an opera character still portrayed in yellow-face today (San Francisco Opera: Madame Butterfly) - I was objectified. Because I resembled the ladies in silk robes giving massages to Chris Tucker in the Rush Hour series, I was hypersexualized. Like the courageous Asian womxn that sought a better life across the Pacific, only to be outlawed and assumed prostitutes by the unjust Page Law of 1875, I was stereotyped. All assumed, without consent. 

Well, my great great grandparents did not toil through the extreme anti-Asian violence and the dehumanizing rhetoric of the mid-19th century or build the damn railroad for nothing. They did not struggle, sacrifice, or withstand hatred for their 5th generation offspring to continue to feel such feelings of  anguish, shame, and powerlessness. 

So I am pushing back.

By illustrating my truths, I am breaking the silence and making my struggle as an Asian-American womxn and the greater struggle of womxn of color VISIBLE & LOUD. Silence is invisibility, squandering true democracy; silence allows conformity to reign supreme - like the saying goes: "Only dead fish swim with the stream." By making the invisible, visible; bringing the marginalized to the center; we are actively resisting the status quo, we are actively swimming against the currents of complacency and conformity. We must go upstream.  

I, an Asian-American womxn, wish to visually say "Fuck you!" to the exoticizing, stereotyping, confining, and objectifying - the mechanisms by which the systematic oppression of womxn of color operate. 

Moreso than just a "Fuck You", I would also like to shed light on the multifaceted emotional experience of this specific form of systemic oppression . The fist as an homage to the legacy and impact of social justice movements, community organizing, and empowerment; the peace sign indicating the importance of expressing resistance against structural inequities and how this is in fact a form of holistic peace-making.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Contributing funds to this Indiegogo Campaign will mean actively engaging with and redefining the national culture we are all perpetuating on a daily basis. Donating to this cause will mean making the struggles of Asian-American womxn and the greater community of womxn of color VISIBLE and LOUD. Donating will indeed be an act of resistance to the oppressive system at hand. Contributing funds would actualize this American ideal of democracy; using cultural production as a means of establishing aesthetic and political representation (big ups to homegroh Lisa Lowe).   Donating would mean rewriting mainstream culture, and reimagining the historical landscape of Asian-America. Donating would also give you a lovely new thread with my icon on the front (4" x 7"), vinyl stickers and oodles of love and gratitude! 

My goal of $6,500 will cover the production of 300 cotton tees, 3,000 vinyl stickers, and the postage/shipping costs. The only set-back would be the length of time for production and shipping - it would take up to 3 weeks to produce and 2 weeks to ship them to contributors. 

Shirt (conveniently mocked-up on a white dude...haha):

Sticker (will be die-cut) :

Remember: we are the architects of this human experience and our collective existence. We have the responsibility and power to imagine and create a sustainable, inclusive, and freer tomorrow. 

Thank you for your generous time. Gratitude always.

Donating to this cause will mean making the struggles of Asian-American womxn and the greater community of womxn of color VISIBLE and LOUD. Donating will indeed be an act of resistance to the oppressive system at hand. Contributing funds would actualize this American ideal of democracy; using cultural production as a means of establishing aesthetic and political representation (big ups to homegroh Lisa Lowe).   Donating would mean rewriting mainstream culture, and reimagining the historical landscape of Asian-America. Donating would also give you a lovely new thread with my icon on the front (4" x 7"), vinyl stickers and oodles of love and gratitude! My goal of $6,500 will cover the production of 300 cotton tees, 3,000 vinyl stickers, and the postage/shipping costs. The only set-back would be the length of time for production and shipping - it would take up to 3 weeks to produce and 2 weeks to ship them to contributors. Shirt (conveniently mocked-up on a white dude...haha):


Sticker (will be die-cut) :

Remember: we are the architects of this human experience and our collective existence. We have the responsibility and power to imagine and create a sustainable, inclusive, and freer tomorrow. Thank you for your generous time. Gratitude always.

story:
Can we infiltrate the mundane mainstream?


Can we challenge the black and grey machine?


Can we bring colour, imagery and psychedelia back to our waking dreams?


Yes. Yes we can.


We all like pretty things.

Sometimes pretty things capture moments,

sometimes they capture minds,

sometimes they open moments,

sometimes they open minds.

I just want you to have some of my art on some stickers.


Hello! Dear friends, known and unknown. I am here to ask for your help.

I have been wanting to print stickers for a very very long time. And now, I have begun.

I have a lot of reservations about creating a crowd fund for my art. But ultimately, this is how I can change my world. By sharing symbols. Creating symbols that offer a window in the known and unknown. Windows into moments, windows into minds.


It costs around $100 per printing run for each sticker, and I have about 7 so far, one lot in the post on its way to me. It would be amazing if I could print all of them. Wow.


Praise be to the internet.

To you.


Please help me by sharing this campaign for

my strange, colourful, psychedelic dreams on your networks.

Thank you so much.

story:
Short Summary

In Phase I the AppleByte Foundation raised $50,000+ to fund the development and server infrastructure for the digital currency, AppleByte. That work was completed in 2014. Learn more at http://applebyte.me

AppleBytes have since been donated and tipped to 500+ artists around the globe, to musicians, painters, sculptors, dancers, actors, film makers, writers, photographers, designers, directors and many more. Meet some of them on our Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/applebyteme

AppleByte went live May 1, 2014, and since then has grown by word of mouth to a user community in the tens of thousands, 35,000+ on social media alone.

In Phase II our budget is $1,000,000 raised from individual art lovers, art foundations, and substantial donors supporting the arts. The funding will be used for marketing & advertising, additional staff, and increased server infrastructure.

What We Need

The AppleByte Foundation will use the additional funding, as follows

  • Print, internet, social media advertising & PR Campaigns.
  • Salaries of two additional full-time staff for marketing and advertising.
  • Funding additional places for artists to spend AppleBytes

Benefits to artists 

Around the world, talented artists slave away, barely able to make a living. The mission of AppleByte is to fund and promote these artists, providing a chance for their careers to grow and their talent to flourish. 
Through the new technology of digital currencies, AppleByte is a person-to-person worldwide payment system to provide artistic freedom, allowing individuals to support the art they love, free of government, corporate or regional restraint.

Here is what we have done already
  • The AppleByte Infrastructure and digital currency has been developed, tested and proven successful worldwide.
  • Over 500 artists have received awards, donations & tips of AppleBytes from the foundation and art lovers worldwide.
  • The foundation gives artists many places to redeem AppleBytes, including gift cards from Amazon, American Express, Visa, AMC Theaters, music downloads, restaurants and many others.
  • We have a dedicated social media community of 35,000+ artists & art lovers who discusses, supports and promotes artists around the world.
  • An app for tipping artists, allows fans to send tips & donations instantly to any artist, anywhere via their Twitter account.
  • A music download site that pays musicians 100% of the sales proceeds, (free to list, no fees ever), is now the highest paying music download site for musicians.
  • A wallet app that runs on MAC, Windows, and Android allows artists and fans to earn AppleBytes on their own, simply running in the background on their computer.
  • We have an established, experienced team of developers from the US, UK, Germany and Finland.
  • You can learn more about these features at http://applebyte.me

Risks & Challenges

The biggest hurdle we have now, is in educating artists and art lovers on using this new technology of digital currencies and overcoming the negative press surrounding the first digital currency, Bitcoin.

Other Ways You Can Help

Like many artists and art lovers you really desire to support the arts, but just don't have the funds.

You can still make a huge difference in the careers of the artists you like. Just go to the AppleByte website (http://applebyte.me), get started with your own AppleByte wallet, earn AppleBytes yourself, and contribute to the the artists you love. It only costs a little time.

story:
Please Support our Campaign

We are launching this campaign to fund five new and inclusive opportunities for recent graduates. Funds raised will go directly to the beneficiaries, to develop their expertise and increase their confidence. They will be paid fairly for their work and strongly encouraged to contribute to a field that might otherwise seem exclusive and closed.

There is often a lack of support for young art graduates today, particularly those from disadvantaged backgrounds. Our concern is that this will mean a level of exclusion from the cultural sector that is unacceptable. We need your help to do something positive! Please support our campaign to create new opportunities for recent graduates. 


Our 'Subscription' pledge includes forthcoming issues of Afterall journal in print and e-book editions, plus access to the online archive of all back issues.


How Will Contributing Make a Difference?

Success can often be traced back to key opportunities that encourage young graduates to persist in their chosen field. 

Your contribution will directly benefit graduates from underrepresented backgrounds or who are the first in their family to have gone on to higher education. The opportunities will be funded as follows:

  • One twelve-month part-time research placement in the Afterall office at Central Saint Martins (£10,000)
  • Four three-month research and writing bursaries overseen by Afterall editors at Central Saint Martins (£2,500 each)
Any funds raised above our target will go towards creating additional bursaries for recent graduates committed to working in contemporary art research and writing.

A canvas tote bag containing five One Work or Exhibition Histories titles of your choice. A full list of titles in these series can be found on our website.


Why Contribute Now?

Over the next 30 days we ask you to pledge whatever you can afford and in return we will raid our archives so that we can offer something in return. For example, our list of 'perks' includes a limited number of first-edition Afterall publications that are no longer available in bookshops. We only have a small number of these so the sooner you pledge the more choice you will have.

         

'Gordon Matta-Clark: Conical Intersect' and 'Philip Guston: The Studio' are now out of print but we have made copies from our archive available for this campaign.


                                  
'Bas Jan Ader: In Search of the Miraculous' and 'Exhibiting the New Art: "Op Losse Schroeven" and "When Attitudes Become Form" 1969'  are now out of print but we made copies from our archive available for this campaign.

                                 

'Art and Social Change: A Critical Reader’, edited by Will Bradley and Charles Esche and 'Art and the Moving Image: A Critical Reader’, edited by Tanya Leighton, are now out of print but we made copies from our archive available for this campaign. 


               

Sue Tompkins has designed a specially commissioned tote bag, over the last days of our campaign we will be offering this unique tote with rare and out-of-print copies of Afterall journal, starting with the Afterall pilot issue 0.


What is Afterall?

Afterall is a research and publishing partnership between Central Saint Martins (CSM), University of the Arts London; M HKA, Antwerp; the Department of Visual Arts–Open Practice Committee (DOVA–OPC), University of Chicago; and CCS Bard, New York. 

We produce an art journal, several series of books, and are closely involved with the student and research communities at CSM, where Afterall was founded in 1998 by Mark Lewis and Charles Esche. We are affiliated with the MRes Art: Exhibition Studies course at CSM:

http://www.arts.ac.uk/csm/courses/postgraduate/mres-art-exhibition-studies/ 

Afterall is an Arts Council England National Portfolio Organisation and part of a growing network of institutions invested in contemporary art research and committed to the idea that art, and writing on art, should be critically independent of the art market. 


Please Spread the Word

Over the years we have collaborated with many providers of mentoring and internship schemes, such as the University of the Arts London Widening Participation programme, which is focused on inclusion and equal opportunity, and the Student Enterprise & Employability department: 

http://www.arts.ac.uk/study-at-ual/widening-participation/

http://www.arts.ac.uk/student-jobs-and-careers/


We are experienced at offering graduates career opportunities, and believe that they make a real difference. It's important to demonstrate that schemes designed to support young graduates can, even in a moment of political austerity, be carried out fairly. We would like to see more young people working within the arts without being exploited as unpaid volunteers.

We would be grateful if you could spread the word to anyone that might help. Please tweet, share and tell your friends. Thank you!

Rodney Graham, Sous Chef on Smoke Break (blue), 2011, photograph printed on bamboo paper, 57.8 x 53.3cm, edition of 200, unframed. Available as part of the 'Edition', 'Patron' and 'The Full Set' pledges.

Please note pledge amounts are inclusive of VAT (where applicable). Pledges do not include international courier costs, which will be billed separately at the point of shipping.

story:
L’associazione culturale Pigment Workroom è all’opera, insieme agli artisti italiani Dem (www.demdemonio.com), Lauda (www.graffdonuts.com/graffdonuts-meets-lauda), Soap The Wizard (www.soapthewizard.it) e Alfano (www.alfanoalfano.com), per realizzare Bari Real Estate 2015, il nuovo progetto di arte urbana partecipata che necessita del vostro aiuto per potersi concretizzare.

Le nostre attività hanno principalmente sede all’interno del laboratorio di stampa artistica artigianale a Bari in Via Imperatore Traiano 38, nato con la vincita del bando della Regione Puglia “Principi Attivi 2012” e di “Culturability 2013” promosso dalla Fondazione Unipolis.



Attraverso i fondi reperiti, siamo riusciti nel giugno 2014 a dare vita alla prima edizione di Enziteto Real Estate che ha ospitato artisti del calibro di Alberonero, Alfano, Ciredz, Geometric Bang e Tellas. Le opere tuttora visibili, sono state eseguite a San Pio, quartiere periferico del capoluogo pugliese, ancora oggi chiamato dai suoi abitanti come “Enziteto”.

La seconda edizione (Bari Real Estate 2015) prevede un’estensione del progetto tale da creare un legame ancora più forte fra San Pio e il cuore di Bari, facendo così del quartiere Libertà un nuovo punto focale dell’evento.

La scelta territoriale è ua fattore determinante per lo sviluppo del progetto stesso.

Il nostro interesse è rivolto a coinvolgere chi è meno abituato a confrontarsi con graffiti, street art e arte in genere, puntando alle periferie e alle aree solitamente considerate prive di attenzione nelle nostre città. In tal modo i quartieri decentrati assumono nuove potenzialità culturali, sociali ed economiche offerte dalla partecipazione degli abitanti, degli artisti e dei visitatori alle iniziative preposte. Inoltre, le opere realizzate sono da considerarsi integrate alle strutture e ai quartieri selezionati, quindi come valorizzazione del patrimonio territoriale.

Per raggiungere questo obiettivo è necessario coinvolgere attivamente i residenti nei processi creativi. Solo in questo modo un’opera d’arte potrà dirsi veramente pubblica, poiché risultato di un’autentica mediazione fra gli artisti e il contesto nel quale intervengono. Un’arte urbana che non tradisca la propria natura d’arte proveniente “dal basso” che si oppone alle logiche espositive orientate “dall’alto”. Non èil frutto di una direzione artistica prestabilita ma un arricchirsi reciproco tra l’artista e il cittadino, attraverso la loro interazione costante e la conoscenza del territorio.

L’arte può esser vissuta quotidianamente, osservata, contemplata e immaginata.


Il Nome

Bari Real Estate 2015 è un contenitore di proposte, idee e programmi a medio e lungo termine.  Con questo concept, invitiamo a guardare in maniera diversa le periferie delle nostre città, non senza un tocco di ironia, leggerezza e spensieratezza.  Estate è una parola che, in inglese, può avere molti significati: si pronuncia esteit, e può significare eredità, tenuta di lusso, ma anche ceto sociale. Real Estate è solitamente usato per indicare la messa in vendita di un complesso abitativo signorile o di villeggiatura. In lingua italiana il termine rimanda alla stagione vacanziera dell’anno.  L’idea, paradossale e sarcastica, è che un quartiere popolare e in difficoltà possa per un attimo essere pensato e vissuto come un “real estate”.




VAI ALLA GALLERY / View Gallery


Mission

Lo scorso anno, a San Pio, l’obiettivo principale era quello di attirare l’interesse di media e cittadini verso un quartiere dimenticato, invertendo la rotta periferia-centro. Attraverso l’impatto mediatico internazionale che ne è derivato si è prodotto un flusso di visitatori attratti dalle opere e da una rassegna stampa importante, contribuendo a demolire almeno un po’ l’associazione che l’immaginario collettivo è solito compiere tra il quartiere e la criminalità.

Bari Real Estate 2015 racchiude un’espansione di obiettivi e finalità mirate ad attraversare più aree della città, stimolando interazioni locali, nazionali e internazionali.  Quest’edizione rappresenta una rete cross-culturale che scioglie i confini urbani, liberando le visioni estetiche e sociali ormai del tutto stereotipate.

Pigment WR si avvarrà del supporto dell’Accademia del Cinema dei Ragazzi di Enziteto (www.getcinema.it/accademia.html)e dell’Officina degli Esordi (www.officinadegliesordi.it), nostri partner ufficiali, spazi multiculturali che condividono gli intenti sociali con cui si può giungere al riutilizzo e alla decorazione di spazi rimasti per anni in stato di abbandono e degrado.


Le Nostre Ricompense (#1 - Lauda)

Ecco cosa produrrà Pigment per sostenere il proprio progetto.

Questo è una parte di quello che avrete in cambio del vostro contributo. Elenco in costante aggiornamento. Tutte le opere sono firmate e certificate.





Due Quartieri

I due quartieri hanno nelle loro costituzioni quasi opposte dei punti in comune dai quali far partire la nostra ricerca.

San Pio, così ribattezzato dall’amministrazione una decina di anni fa, è un complesso di case popolari costruite negli anni ’50 in un’area isolata a nord della città, dove tutte le avanguardistiche strutture pubbliche pensate per il suo auto sostentamento non furono mai messe in funzione, creando sin dalla sua nascita i presupposti per una vera e propria ghettizzazione. I tremila abitanti dispongono di un solo bar, un solo bus, un solo supermercato e un dispensario di medicine.

I casi di criminalità e disagio estremo tardano ad abbandonare San Pio: non esteso né popoloso come Scampia a Napoli o lo Zen a Palermo, il quartiere rimane comunque comunemente associato a questi ultimi per problemi analoghi.

Il quartiere Libertà, con 60mila abitanti, è il più popoloso di Bari. A differenza di San Pio, il Libertà è situato a immediato ridosso del centro cittadino e si fa subito notare per la sua edilizia storicamente rilevante, fitta di palazzi costruiti durante la prima metà del Novecento. Durante gli ultimi decenni il quartiere è divenuto oggetto di un crescente degrado e disinteresse delle istituzioni.

La crisi economica ha rafforzato l’animo popolare del cuore abitativo del capoluogo: se da un lato si assiste alla chiusura dei negozi storici di Via Manzoni, dall’altro si vede l’aumento di studenti e giovani lavoratori in cerca di alloggi a buon prezzo.

Per la stessa ragione, sono attirati nel quartiere immigrati provenienti dall’Africa centrale e da tutta l’area asiatica. Talvolta, questi ultimi vengono costretti a piegarsi alle logiche dell’illegalità che non hanno mai lasciato le strade del quartiere.

La cronaca parla spesso di “una terra di nessuno”, teatro di episodi drammatici di criminalità organizzata che ne fanno una sorta di periferia nel cuore di Bari dove i clan si spartiscono le aree di spaccio e il controllo dei traffici. A pagare il prezzo più alto di tutto questo, come sempre, sono i più giovani, specie quelli che cedono al fascino della vita criminale.

Certamente l’arte non può ambire a risolvere i problemi più seri di un quartiere in difficoltà eppure il suo contributo può essere essenziale e la sua presenza un incentivo per i cittadini baresi a trovare o a ritrovare l’interesse per San Pio e per il Libertà: recarvisi significa vedere e sentire l’energia con cui si esprime la forte volontà di riscatto dei residenti, tanto più quando veicolata attraverso attività creative, come quelle encomiabili promosse dall’Accademia del Cinema e dall’Officina degli Esordi.


Il Progetto

Non si tratterà di un semplice intervento di ri-estetizzazione urbana: Pigment e gli artisti invitati coinvolgeranno attivamente i residenti dei quartieri, a partire da quelli più giovani, nelle loro attività artistiche.

Come?

Un corso di graffiti e arti urbane gratuito a cura di Pigment è già attivo, dal giorno 18 aprile 2015 grazie al sostegno dell’Accademia del Cinema dei Ragazzi di Enziteto. Nel quartiere Libertà, il corso sarà avviato mercoledì 27 maggio 2015 grazie al supporto dell’Officina degli Esordi.

Con i nostri studenti under 16 scenderemo fra le loro strade, esploreremo i luoghi che non conosciamo e inviteremo porta a porta tutti gli abitanti a partecipare ai due incontri di quartiere di metà giugno.



A San Pio una lunga giornata di festa accoglierà l’arrivo dei primi due artisti. Una graffiti Jam colorerà le pareti esterne dello Stadio, da anni oggetto di incuria; a seguire, all’interno dell’Accademia del Cinema di Enziteto, sarà presentato il progetto Bari Real Estate 2015 con video e musica dal vivo.

Il quartiere Libertà, con il sostegno di Pophub (www.pophub.it) e dell’Amiu, vedrà l’apertura straordinaria dell’ex Arena Moderno, un cinema all’aperto che per anni ha ospitato generazioni di cinefili. Rimetteremo in sesto un luogo d’incontro abbandonato da tempo; cittadini e artisti disegneranno insieme su supporti che, successivamente, verranno esposti nelle strade limistrofe.

Ad aiutarci ci saranno anche i ragazzi di Metriquali (www.metriquali.it), pronti ad attivare sistemi di recupero degli spazi in disuso tramite l’autocostruzione partecipata, con artisti e cittadini.

I primi due artisti si occuperanno di colorare due grandi pareti delle case popolari di Enziteto e dell’Officina degli Esordi.

Entro settembre saranno almeno tre gli interventi pubblici di grandi dimensioni. Nostro obiettivo è raccogliere più fondi possibili per poter così ampliare il programma e ospitare un maggior numero di artisti.

A fine settembre l’Officina degli Esordi ospiterà una mostra a cura di Pigment Workroom durante la quale verranno esposte per tutto il mese a seguire le opere su carta e tessuto realizzate.



Cosa sta già accadendo

Ecco alcuni interventi di questi giorni (Giugno 2015).

[Geometric Bang - Bari (Italy)]

[Alfano e Soap The Wizard - Enziteto, Bari (Italy)]




Finalità Della Raccolta Fondi

Per sostenere i propri progetti Pigment produrrà e metterà in vendita serigrafie e risografie d’artista, numerate e firmate, ma anche capi d’abbigliamento, prodotti editoriali e gadget. Tutto il materiale sarà vostra disposizione al 20% in meno rispetto al loro valore commerciale: il vostro aiuto è fondamentale affinché si possano sostenere le spese di comunicazione, del materiale artistico, dei viaggi, del vitto e dell’alloggio degli artisti, compreso tutto ciò di cui un evento di questa portata necessità.


DIFFONDETE E SUPPORTATE.

GRAZIE!

Le Nostre Ricompense (2 - Soap the Wizard)

Contatti

Soc. Coop. Pigment Workroom
Sede Legale: Via Mauro Amoruso, 96 - Bari 70124 (Italy)
Sede Operativa: Via Imperatore Traiano, 33 - Bari 70121 (Italy)
Email: info@pigment-wr.com
Email: gsantoro@pigment-wr.com
Email: mnardulli@pigment-wr.com
Mobile: (+39) 339 140 80 17





Story

Hi everyone! We are Pigment Workroom, and Bari Real Estate 2015 is a participatory urban art project we want to fulfill. That’s why we are asking for your support.

Ours is a DIY art-printing studio: we build it up in 2014 thanks to a win at a couple of national calls-for-funding. In June 2014 we realized Enziteto Real Estate’s first edition: Italian artists Alberonero, Alfano, Ciredz, Geometric Bang and Tellas worked in San Pio, a suburban neighborhood of Bari, still known among its residents with its old name, “Enziteto”.

At the same time we have built our laboratory piece by piece. There, artists handprint their silkscreen artworks on paper and t-shirts (and this is, for the most part, what we would love to give you in return for your precious help).

Our mission addresses to people not used to cultural and artistic initiatives, for instance the residents of popular and suburban neighborhoods: graffiti and so-called “street art” can, at certain conditions, embody a way of aestheticization of human territories otherwise treated as non-places by politics and public administrations.

The very first condition in order to fulfill this purpose is that residents shall be involved in the whole creative processes. That’s the only way to make art truly “public”, the result of mediation between the artists and the context in which they intervene. Urban art’s nature is grassroots: it is not something that one imposes upon a community like, for instance, a commercial billboard. It’s not a hit-and-run, nor the result of a preset artistic direction: it is rather a mutual enrichment between the artist and the citizen, a result that can only be achieved through their interaction and the knowledge of the territory.

Mission

The event’s first edition aimed to attract media and citizens’ attention towards a forgotten neighborhood and that’s what we succeeded to obtain: reversing the “first downtown, then suburbs” logic, and generating international media impact. Enziteto Real Estate induced a remarkable flux of visitors thanks to the appeal of the murals, as well as a huge media coverage: this contributed to demolish a little bit the association between the neighborhood and criminality which is still deep-rooted in the collective consciousness.

The title we chose for the project aims to this precise target, not without a certain irony. In English, the word Estate has more than one meaning: heritage, a luxury property or even social class. Real Estate is usually employed to mean a high-class residence for sale. In Italian, Estate means summer.

The sarcastic idea that a suburban neighborhood could, even just for a moment, be imagined as a “real estate” or a luxury residence for a summer vacation, is a way to invite people to look differently to these types of districts. Our mission for the second edition is to create an even stronger bond between San Pio and Bari downtown, this time by implicating Libertà’s district.


Two Neighborhoods

San Pio and Libertà are utterly dissimilar from a mere aesthetic standpoint. Nevertheless, they have quite a lot of common ground.

San Pio (thus renamed around ten years ago) is a complex of social housing buildings erected during the 1950s in an isolated area, located up north of the city, devoid of fundamental public structures and commercial activities. Ever since then, San Pio is a sort of ghetto: its 3,000 inhabitants only have one coffee shop, one bus line, and one supermarket. Not even a true drugstore. Criminal rates and social disadvantage are still a fact.

Libertà is, on the other hand, the most populous district of Bari, counting around 60,000 inhabitants. In contrast with San Pio, this neighborhood is located right next to downtown and is architecturally relevant: the most part of its buildings has been erected during the first half of 1900, even though today it undergoes an increasing neglect and a lack of interest from the institutions. Financial crisis led to a drop of rental fares, thus leading to an increase of young and immigrant population and improving the “popular soul” of this neighborhood. However, Libertà is often a scene of criminal acts, a “no-man’s land” where gangs fight for the control of the streets and the drug trade.

Art cannot be charged with responsibilities that should rather be of administrations and politics, like solving all by itself problems such as those of San Pio and Libertà. Anyway, its presence can certainly play an important role in transforming viewpoints and triggering changes. Our mission is to reactivate the attention and the interest of Bari’s citizens for these two neighborhoods: visiting San Pio and Libertà would mean seeing and feeling the longing for social recognition of their residents, and their energy and commitment when involved in creative activities.


The Project

It won’t be a plain and simple intervention of urban re-aestheticization: Pigment and the invited artists will actively involve the residents, from children to the elderly, in their artistic activities.

How will we do so?

A graffiti and urban art free workshop curated by Pigment has already been activated on April 18 in San Pio. Starting mid-May there will be one in Libertà as well.

We will go on the streets with our under-16 students to explore places we don’t know yet, then we will invite each resident to take part in two events that will occur mid-June:

In San Pio, the first two invited artists will paint the outside walls of the local stadium, then a party will start at the Cinema Academy with film screening and live music.

In Libertà we will re-activate for a day a former open-air theater named “Arena Moderno”: artists and residents will paint together, then their artworks will be part of an exhibition located in the streets nearby the theater.

Before September, the invited artists will also paint two huge walls in San Pio and Libertà, and at the end of the month we will organize a closing party with a live concert, the screening of all the documentary material and an exhibition with each artwork and apparel produced by the artists in our studio.

Why A Fundrasing

In order to support this project, Pigment will produce silk-screen limited-edition prints and Risograph limited edition prints, made by the invited artists, each one of them numbered and signed. We will also produce apparel, editorial items and gadgets. All of these items will be given as rewards at -20% of their actual market value: your help is fundamental for us in order to support the whole production cost of the project, which includes travels, food and housing for the artists, communication and materials.

It’s quite simple: the more funds we raise, the more artists will come to Bari and the more walls will be painted in San Pio and Libertà. So, help us and share this page as much as possible! And don’t hesitate to be in touch with us if you want to be our sponsor.


SHARE THIS AND SUPPORT US.

THANKS A LOT!

Artists (to date)

Soap The Wizard (www.soapthewizard.it)
Lauda (www.graffdonuts.com/graffdonuts-meets-lauda)
Dem (www.demdemonio.com)
Alfano (www.alfanoalfano.com)


Contacts

Soc. Coop. Pigment Workroom
Office: Via Mauro Amoruso, 96 - Bari 70124 (Italy)
Headquarters: Via Imperatore Traiano, 33 - Bari 70121 (Italy)
Email: info@pigment-wr.com
Email: gsantoro@pigment-wr.com
Email: mnardulli@pigment-wr.com
Mobile: (+39) 339 140 80 17
story_txt:
L’associazione culturale Pigment
Workroom è all’opera, insieme agli artisti italiani Dem (www.demdemonio.com), Lauda (www.graffdonuts.com/graffdonuts-meets-lauda), Soap The Wizard (www.soapthewizard.it) e Alfano (www.alfanoalfano.com), per realizzare Bari Real Estate
2015, il nuovo
progetto di arte urbana partecipata che necessita del vostro aiuto per potersi
concretizzare. 


Le
nostre attività hanno principalmente sede all’interno del laboratorio di stampa
artistica artigianale a Bari in Via Imperatore Traiano 38, nato con la vincita
del bando della Regione Puglia “Principi
Attivi 2012” e di “Culturability
2013” promosso dalla Fondazione Unipolis.



Attraverso i fondi reperiti, siamo riusciti nel giugno 2014 a dare vita
alla prima edizione di Enziteto Real Estate che ha ospitato
artisti del calibro di Alberonero, Alfano, Ciredz, Geometric Bang e
Tellas. Le opere tuttora visibili, sono state eseguite a San Pio, quartiere
periferico del capoluogo pugliese, ancora oggi chiamato dai suoi
abitanti come “Enziteto”. 
La seconda edizione (Bari Real Estate 2015) prevede un’estensione del
progetto tale da creare un legame ancora più forte fra San Pio e il cuore di
Bari, facendo così del quartiere Libertà un nuovo punto focale dell’evento.
La scelta territoriale è ua fattore determinante per lo sviluppo del
progetto stesso. 
Il nostro interesse è rivolto a coinvolgere chi è meno abituato a
confrontarsi con graffiti, street art e arte in genere, puntando alle periferie e alle aree solitamente considerate prive
di attenzione nelle nostre città. In tal modo i quartieri decentrati assumono
nuove potenzialità culturali, sociali ed economiche offerte dalla
partecipazione degli abitanti, degli artisti e dei visitatori alle iniziative
preposte. Inoltre, le opere realizzate sono da considerarsi integrate alle
strutture e ai quartieri selezionati, quindi come valorizzazione del patrimonio
territoriale.
Per raggiungere questo obiettivo è necessario coinvolgere attivamente i residenti nei processi creativi. Solo in
questo modo un’opera d’arte potrà dirsi veramente pubblica, poiché risultato di
un’autentica mediazione fra gli artisti e il contesto nel quale intervengono. Un’arte
urbana che non tradisca la propria natura d’arte proveniente “dal basso” che si oppone alle logiche espositive orientate
“dall’alto”. Non èil frutto di una direzione artistica prestabilita ma
un arricchirsi reciproco tra l’artista e il cittadino, attraverso la loro
interazione costante e la conoscenza del territorio.

L’arte può esser vissuta quotidianamente,
osservata, contemplata e immaginata.

Il Nome
 Bari Real Estate 2015 è un contenitore di proposte,
idee e programmi a medio e lungo termine. 
Con questo concept, invitiamo
a guardare in maniera diversa le periferie delle nostre città, non senza un
tocco di ironia, leggerezza e spensieratezza.  
Estate è una parola che, in inglese, può avere molti
significati: si pronuncia esteit, e
può significare eredità, tenuta di lusso, ma anche ceto sociale. Real Estate
è solitamente usato per indicare la messa in vendita di un complesso
abitativo signorile o di villeggiatura. In lingua italiana il termine rimanda
alla stagione vacanziera dell’anno.  L’idea, paradossale e sarcastica, è che un
quartiere popolare e in difficoltà possa per un attimo essere pensato e vissuto come un “real estate”.



VAI ALLA GALLERY / View Gallery
 
Mission
 
Lo scorso anno, a San Pio, l’obiettivo principale era quello di attirare l’interesse
di media e cittadini verso un quartiere dimenticato, invertendo la rotta periferia-centro. Attraverso l’impatto
mediatico internazionale che ne è derivato si è prodotto un flusso di
visitatori attratti dalle opere e da una rassegna stampa importante,
contribuendo a demolire almeno un po’ l’associazione che l’immaginario
collettivo è solito compiere tra il quartiere e la criminalità. 
Bari Real
Estate 2015 racchiude un’espansione di obiettivi e finalità
mirate ad attraversare più aree della città, stimolando interazioni locali,
nazionali e internazionali.  Quest’edizione
rappresenta una rete cross-culturale che scioglie i confini urbani, liberando
le visioni estetiche e sociali ormai del tutto stereotipate. 

Pigment WR si avvarrà del supporto dell’Accademia del Cinema dei Ragazzi di
Enziteto (www.getcinema.it/accademia.html)e dell’Officina degli Esordi (www.officinadegliesordi.it), nostri partner ufficiali, spazi multiculturali
che condividono gli intenti sociali con cui si può giungere al riutilizzo e
alla decorazione di spazi rimasti per anni in stato di abbandono e degrado.Le Nostre Ricompense (#1 - Lauda)

Ecco cosa produrrà Pigment per sostenere il proprio progetto.
Questo è una parte di quello che avrete in cambio del vostro contributo. 
Elenco in costante aggiornamento. Tutte le opere sono firmate e certificate.


   Due Quartieri
  
I due quartieri hanno nelle loro costituzioni quasi
opposte dei punti in comune dai quali far partire la nostra ricerca.
San Pio, così
ribattezzato dall’amministrazione una decina di anni fa, è un complesso di case
popolari costruite negli anni ’50 in un’area isolata a nord della città, dove tutte
le avanguardistiche strutture pubbliche pensate per il suo auto sostentamento
non furono mai messe in funzione, creando sin dalla sua nascita i presupposti
per una vera e propria ghettizzazione. I tremila abitanti dispongono di un solo
bar, un solo bus, un solo supermercato e un dispensario di medicine. 
I casi di
criminalità e disagio estremo tardano ad abbandonare San Pio: non
esteso né popoloso come Scampia a Napoli o lo Zen a Palermo, il quartiere
rimane comunque comunemente associato a questi ultimi per problemi analoghi. 
Il quartiere
Libertà, con 60mila abitanti, è il più popoloso di Bari. A differenza di
San Pio, il Libertà è situato a immediato ridosso del centro cittadino e si fa
subito notare per la sua edilizia storicamente rilevante, fitta di palazzi
costruiti durante la prima metà del Novecento. Durante gli ultimi decenni il
quartiere è divenuto oggetto di un crescente degrado e disinteresse delle
istituzioni.
La crisi economica ha rafforzato l’animo popolare del cuore abitativo
del capoluogo: se da un lato si assiste alla chiusura dei negozi storici di Via
Manzoni, dall’altro si vede l’aumento di studenti e giovani lavoratori in cerca
di alloggi a buon prezzo. 
Per la stessa ragione, sono attirati nel quartiere
immigrati provenienti dall’Africa centrale e da tutta l’area asiatica.
Talvolta, questi ultimi vengono costretti a piegarsi alle logiche dell’illegalità che non hanno mai lasciato le strade del quartiere.
La cronaca parla spesso di “una terra di nessuno”, teatro
di episodi drammatici di criminalità organizzata che ne fanno una sorta di periferia nel cuore di Bari
dove i clan si spartiscono le aree di spaccio e il controllo dei traffici. A
pagare il prezzo più alto di tutto questo, come sempre, sono i più giovani,
specie quelli che cedono al fascino della vita criminale.

Certamente l’arte non può ambire a risolvere i
problemi più seri di un quartiere in difficoltà eppure il suo contributo può essere
essenziale e la sua presenza un incentivo per i cittadini baresi a trovare
o a ritrovare l’interesse per San Pio e per il Libertà: recarvisi significa
vedere e sentire l’energia con cui si esprime la forte volontà di riscatto
dei residenti, tanto più quando veicolata attraverso attività
creative, come quelle encomiabili promosse dall’Accademia del Cinema e
dall’Officina degli Esordi.

Il Progetto
 
Non si tratterà di un semplice intervento di ri-estetizzazione
urbana: Pigment e gli artisti invitati coinvolgeranno attivamente i
residenti dei quartieri, a partire da quelli più giovani, nelle loro attività
artistiche. 

Come?
Un corso di graffiti e arti urbane gratuito a
cura di Pigment è già attivo, dal giorno 18 aprile 2015 grazie al sostegno
dell’Accademia del Cinema dei Ragazzi di Enziteto. Nel quartiere Libertà, il corso sarà avviato
mercoledì 27 maggio 2015 grazie al supporto dell’Officina degli Esordi.
Con i nostri studenti under 16 scenderemo fra le
loro strade, esploreremo i luoghi che non conosciamo e inviteremo porta a porta
tutti gli abitanti a partecipare ai due
incontri di quartiere di metà giugno.





A San Pio una lunga giornata di festa accoglierà
l’arrivo dei primi due artisti. Una graffiti
Jam colorerà le pareti esterne dello Stadio, da anni oggetto di incuria; a
seguire, all’interno dell’Accademia del Cinema di Enziteto, sarà presentato il
progetto Bari Real Estate 2015 con video e musica dal vivo.
Il quartiere Libertà, con il sostegno di Pophub (www.pophub.it) e dell’Amiu, vedrà l’apertura straordinaria dell’ex Arena Moderno, un cinema all’aperto
che per anni ha ospitato generazioni di cinefili. Rimetteremo in sesto un luogo
d’incontro abbandonato da tempo; cittadini e artisti disegneranno insieme su
supporti che, successivamente, verranno esposti nelle strade limistrofe.
Ad aiutarci ci saranno anche i ragazzi di Metriquali (www.metriquali.it), pronti ad attivare
sistemi di recupero degli spazi in disuso tramite l’autocostruzione
partecipata, con artisti e cittadini.
I primi due artisti si occuperanno di colorare due grandi pareti delle case
popolari di Enziteto e dell’Officina degli Esordi. 
Entro settembre saranno almeno tre gli interventi
pubblici di grandi dimensioni. Nostro obiettivo è raccogliere più fondi
possibili per poter così ampliare il programma e ospitare un maggior numero di artisti.

A fine settembre l’Officina degli Esordi ospiterà
una mostra a cura di Pigment
Workroom durante la quale verranno esposte per tutto il mese a seguire le opere
su carta e tessuto realizzate.Cosa sta già accadendo 

Ecco alcuni interventi di questi giorni (Giugno 2015).

[Geometric Bang - Bari (Italy)]
[Alfano e Soap The Wizard - Enziteto, Bari (Italy)]

Per sostenere i propri progetti Pigment
produrrà e metterà in vendita serigrafie e risografie d’artista,
numerate e firmate, ma anche capi d’abbigliamento, prodotti editoriali
e gadget. Tutto il materiale sarà vostra disposizione al 20% in meno
rispetto al loro valore commerciale: il vostro aiuto è fondamentale affinché si
possano sostenere le spese di comunicazione, del materiale artistico, dei
viaggi, del vitto e dell’alloggio degli artisti, compreso tutto ciò di cui un
evento di questa portata necessità.



DIFFONDETE E SUPPORTATE.
GRAZIE!

 Soap The Wizard (www.soapthewizard.it)

Questo è una parte di quello che avrete in cambio del vostro contributo. 
Elenco in costante aggiornamento. Tutte le opere sono firmate e certificate.







 Contatti

Soc. Coop. Pigment Workroom
Sede Legale: Via Mauro Amoruso, 96 - Bari 70124 (Italy)
Sede Operativa: Via Imperatore Traiano, 33 - Bari 70121 (Italy)
Email: info@pigment-wr.com

story:
Aeon Sticker & Button Graphic

MAJOR PLAYA ART

Jub Jub World Projects is wildly excited about bringing this Major Art Installation to Black Rock City in 2016.  Several years in the incubation stage, this is the exact right time for the idea to come to fruition. We hope you can take full advantage of this opportunity to help bring this magic to our alternate universe of Burning Man.

THE TEAM

The project team consists of dedicated Artists and Constructors, well experienced in bringing Major Art to the playa for over two decades. The primary players were builders of colossal Man Bases and Pavilions for ten of those years. We have the itch to “build big” again. 

MAKING IT HAPPEN

Playa Art of this magnitude is what makes Burning Man the memorable, jaw dropping experience it is. Our intent is to make Aeon a top destination and interactive opportunity for all the Citizens of Black Rock City. And to cap that off, a spectacular burn. The primary purpose of this funding campaign is to encourage full Burning Man community support for this project. It’s obviously a lot of collaborative work to pull this off. We’ll be looking for your help with all the various “hands on” aspects of making the project happen, as well as, your financial support.  

We truly appreciate your support and participation!

Even if unable to contribute at this time, please share this with your friends.

            Aeon Bandana Graphic

THE ARTISTIC CONCEPT STUFF

“The Vector Equilibrium is the starting point for happenings and non happenings: it is the empty theater and empty circus and empty Universe ready to accommodate any act and any audience.”  Buckminster Fuller

Project Aeon explores the concept of Vector Equilibrium (VE) and how it's expressed in all that we perceive as matter, our physical reality. The visual representation of the VE form, as a spherical Torus, eludes to the bodies of energy that compose all of our Universe. It reflects the electromagnetic flow of energy that structures these bodies, from the entire Universe itself, to stars, planets, atoms and subatomic systems, even our own human bodies. Sacred geometry is unveiled in the systems of this form and infinitely replicates itself throughout the structure. Light is the focus of the interactive aspect of the project.


The design promotes a staged level of experience by placement, deep out in open playa to make it a destination. Upon arrival to the 50’ tall structure, spreading out over a 120’ diameter footprint, bikes and Art Cars will be left at the perimeter and entry will be at three gateway Torus points. The courtyard and playa level space under the Mezzanine will provide a pedestrian gathering and resting opportunity, without the clutter of bikes and other obstacles. Torus related large scale interactive “toys” will be in the courtyard and under the Mezzanine Deck to illustrate the Sacred Geometry concepts found within the project. The joyful spinning of the Torus sculptures on the Mezzanine and interactive hubbub in the Crystal Pavilion will draw participants up the spiral stairs to join in the interaction. Once up there, and participating in the visual and kinetic opportunities the sculptures offer, the views back towards fabulous Black Rock City and Desert can be enjoyed from these higher vantage points. 

Aeon Medallion Perk - 2" h. stainless steel with silver tone spring ring 
and 24" cord.

Aeon Ceremonial Burn Hat Perk - Our Artists will customize colors and any additional fun accessories to the design with fur, feathers, el wire trim, fake gems, etc. (probably not any precious gems, unless you'd like to supply them.)

Aeon Interactive Torus Sculpture - Approximately 5' high x 5' diameter and designed to revolve, with large Swarovski crystals mounted in the panels. The design will be customized for the perk donor. We have many concepts already developed to stimulate the imagination.

campaign_city: Black Rock City, NV, United States

story:
About project

We are working on limited book edition named "Castrum Vallis" which is held every year from 1964 till today. On the occasion of 50 year anniversary of the exhibition 250 copies of the book will be made in hot stamped gold foil cover and numbered from 1 to 250.

Because of the hot stamped gold foil the each book will be unique.

Book contains works of all 77 authors participating on 50 year anniversary exibition. Book also contains foreword on the 50 year occasion.
The book is made in top digital print.

Sewing , binding, numbering and hot stamped is handmade.




About exibition:

L.CastrumVallis(1964. – 2014.)

One can't stay indiferent faced with fifty years of activity, this 50 year anniversary birthday is a ceremony with a special meaning, but every other meetings were also very special and inspirational to the artists and visitiors who are no longer accidental visitors but respectable guests who, with the calendar in hand, impatiently wait in line for the opening of the exhibition doors. First page of this catalog should be left empty so we all could have an opportunity to enter our impressions which will, afterwards, published as independent book, but we need to be reminded of the long road to leading to this point, and without any doubt, we should quote the lines from the prologues of previous catalogs. First paint exhibition “CastrumVallis” was in distant 1964. year and continued every summer till today. This one of a kind cultural event was developed from love for the fine arts of the Bale city residents and it represents cultural event of the year for not only residents of Castrum but for all temporary visitiors. This is an exibition without hierarchy and restrictions, we can find academic paintings next to amateur paintings, applied arts next to conceptual art. The main theme of the exhibition is unity of the municipality and celebration of creativity we all share. “CastrumVallis” is a fact, an positive event, witouth judging, witouth stictly defined theme and this are all preconditions for strenght and longevity of this visual manifestation. Concept of the exhibition is just as imagined by its founders Dragica Cvek-Jordan i V.Josip Jordan who describe this in a short review:

“In the mid of 60's, when the three of us (Jordan, Cvek-Jordan i Cmelic) strated to gather artists in Castrum Vallisa (Dragičević, H. Schvabenitz, F. Dedić joined us later), exibition was small, on the opening celabration visitors were from Rovinj, Pula etc., we were young and full of enthusiasm, and back then Bale had all the charachteristics of middleage town (past times). We are happy to see this artist expirience had hold on for such a long time, there were the years of crysis, and sometimes the lack of understanding but, it is important that “CastrumVallis” has becomed a cultural part not only in Bale but in whole Istra and even more. Bale are without any doubt an “Eternal story”, so this is the theme of this year exhibition; this is at the same time a fact and a hope that will inspire artists and exhibitors feelings, emotions and personal visions, from different perspectives always under umbrella of “CASTRUM VALLIS”.

Some works in limited edition:

story:
What is Sexual Babel?

The Tower of Babel, a story from the Book of Genesis, describes the origin of different languages and their disbursement around the world. As the story goes, humanity communicated via one universal language, and the people attempted to build a tower as high as the heavens, God, challenged by the possible power of a united community, dispersed humanity around the world causing the destruction of a universal language and the birth of a multilingual world. Although the story seems negative since communication became complicated, it also illustrates the birth of diversified expression and celebrates a variety of cultures. 

Sex, also an integral part of our existence, holds a variety of languages which we use to connect, empower, oppress, and liberate. So let’s talk about that core communicative component of life: 

Throughout history cultures have worshiped, punished, denied, and explored sexuality, and now we have the opportunity to draw from those ancestral definitions and reflect on our own sexual identities in a global context: Sexual Babel.

What is sexuality? Is it a fixed and innate desire unaffected by choice? Or does our environment and experience influence our attraction and ability to intimately relate?  How do we balance the individual and collective identification of sexuality?

Sexual Babel explores and honors the representation of sex and various expressions of sexuality over time. Seven beautifully etched, mixed media totems are arranged in a protective circle, representing different historical belief systems about sexuality. The circle collectively represents sexuality, globally and historically, through form and photography, and encapsulates a lit pyramid of individual sexual expression. The pyramid itself connotes the connectedness that the Tower of Babel strove to unite, ultimately leading to the understanding that sexual power is not fixed and rather a fluid internal energy sustained by external relationships. 

Totems:

Each totem represents different cultural deities throughout history and an associated aspect of sexuality. The totems and their representations include:

Aztec: Gender Neutrality

Xochiquetzal​ (the goddess of fertility, beauty,prostitutes and female sexual power) and her brother X​ochipilli​ (the god of love, art, beauty, dance, fertility, and song)

Aztec Totem Sketch

Chinese: Sexual Objectification

Exterior Panel of Chinese Totem

T​u Er Shen (​the god of love between homosexual men) and P​an Jinlian (​the goddess of fornication and prostitution)

Hindu: Sexual Spirituality

K​amadeva (the god of love and sexuality), his wife R​ati​ (the goddess of passion and lust), along with P​arvati (​the goddess of love, devotion, and fertility)

Mesopotamia/Babylonian/Greek: Ability to Explore Sexuality and Gender

Exterior of Mesopotamian Totem 

Love Goddesses: Inanna (war and fertility), Ishtar(sex, fertility, and war), and Aphrodite(pleasure, beauty, and procreation)

Moroccan: Female Sexuality

Q​andisa (​the goddess of lust who seduces men and then drives them insane)

Norse: Male Sexuality

F​reyr (​a phallic fertility god bestowing peace and pleasure on mortals)

Voodoo: Sex Positivity

B​aron Samedi​ (the god of death, sex, and resurrection)

Voodoo Totem Sketch

Photography:

The display of black and white photography within each totem creates a stark, contemplative space. Each totem contains two photographs representing the spectrum of the brightest possibilities when these sexual values are embraced and also the darkest impacts of sexual oppression. The series of images cover broad and complex spectrums of sexuality including sex trafficking, androgyny, fetishes, queer culture and more. 

An image representative of androgyny for the Aztec totem on Gender Neutrality

An image representative of sex trafficking for the Chinese Totem on Sexual Objectification


Pyramid:

At the center of the circle stands an acrylic pyramid (approximately 5 feet tall) covered in an array of RGB LEDs displaying multicolored animations, representing the fluidity of sexual energy.


LED Pyramid prototype- imagine it 5 feet tall animated with rainbow waves of love!

Individuals can write on the pyramid with colored sharpies expressing thoughts, feelings, ideas, and ultimately their own sexual identity as it relates to the sacred sexual space.


Ceremony:

This diverse expression of sexuality will culminate in a ceremony, held on Wednesday September 2nd at 7pm on the playa, honoring each god and goddess, sex positivity, introspection, and acceptance. Through the ceremony we can cast aside old hang-ups, self-doubts, and frustrations as we create a circle to invoke and honor sexual deities from around the world and ask for their healing support both for ourselves and the world at large. 


What We Still Need:

Here's the list of project material cost breakdown:

Acrylic Panels for the pyramid: $800

Additional LEDs for the pyramid: $600

Printed photographs for the interior of the totem: $200

Plastic frames to protect the photographs: $200

Additional art supplies for final totem details: $200

Total: $2000


The Impact:

Sexual Babel aims to raise awareness around sexuality, both individually and collectively. Participants are able to wander through the space, and reflect on and express their own sexual identity. The multitude of sexual expressions in the space display the diversity and fluidity of sexual identity while illustrating the power of choice and privilege associated with that choice. 

This interactive art piece stands as a conscious-raising effort around the temporality of labels and their subjective significance, allowing participants to examine chosen labels and confront socially constructed expectations that do not align with internal identifications. By supporting Sexual Babel you're helping to create a sex positive space that encourages participants to question, challenge, and explore the various ways sexuality shapes our perceptions of the self and relationship to others. 


Other Ways You Can Help:

If you can't donate then please help spread the word! If you're going to burning man then please join us on the playa on Wednesday evening for our ceremony celebrating sexuality and its diverse expressions.

story:
This is a visual story about a land of Oz where there is the lure of going from rags to riches overnight but it is a place where people go from riches to rags overnight as well.


My name is Ralph Elliott Starkweather and I have been a photographer for many years. I was fortunate enough to be part of a small photo agency called WESTLIGHT founded in 1980 and run by 2 talented and very passionate National Geographic photographers. It was a great 20 years with this agency but the world changed when Microsoft created Corbis Photo Agency which ate up WESTLIGHT and so many of the great and passionate agencies arounfd the world. By doing so they acquired huge collections of worldwide images to sell as stock images.  

Recently I spent 2 days/nights in Las Vegas when I was on my way to Denver Colorado. I found some incredible images in those 2 days. This was not my first time in Las Vegas since I had shot photographs for Cirque Du Soleil in the 90's and a few years ago in 2009 the huge City Center project for a German firm. I also had large art photographs I made of Muhammad Ali, these were photographs taken while traveling and documenting The Champ's world from 1979-1980, these were displayed in Planet Hollywood.

I will spend about a month documenting in my style this world presenting interesting and sometimes humorous, somtimes sad images for an exhibition and small book and ebook downloads. Hopefully I can also set aside a percentage from print and book sales to help the young homeless kids and battered women one encounters in Las Vegas as well. I will deal with the book and exhibition costs with another Indiegogo fundraiser. I want to keep the numbers down here to get started. $ 2500 will allow me to spend enough time to dig down for shooting images I could only find in such a surreal environment.


The reward photographic prints will be printed on the highest quality photographic archival media and will be signed and suitable for framing.

Just a loose accounting here why I am budgeting  $ 2500:

Reward prints approx.  ...........................................   $   200

Lodging  ...................................................................   $  1300

Food  ........................................................................    $   500

Misc, transportation, tips for performers, etc.......   $   500

story:
As a passionate teacher of young children I see the damage caused by neglect and abuse of our little ones. As a person I can say that my family has experienced this insidious dark side of humanity. As a writer and story teller, I feel empowered to tell my story to the world.

My objective with this short film is to project some of my observations of life into a compelling and relevant story. This I hope will go some way to instill confidence into our young people which still suffer in silence – to tell someone they trust.

By contributing generously, this story and the message within has the capacity to become a national and international tool in the fight against this ubiquitous social malady. There are a number of child advocacy groups in Australia that could benefit from a professional, well executed story serving a higher purpose. I want to provide them all with something explosive, engaging and most of all useful.

Story: Sophie has been through hell as a child. If she is to emancipate herself, she must face the darkness of her past head on.

While I have secured some funding for this project it is limited to paying 4 cast members and only half my crew. We need $12000, so we can utilize exclusively local talent in the areas of; composing an original score ($2000), theme song ($1500), Epic Red camera hire ($3000), professional sound and lighting ($2000), catering ($1500), major equipment such as crane and dolly ($2000).

Attached is a link to the teaser trailer https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KvaWb3qKULU

We have plenty of talent in this town and we are trying to put North Queensland on the film making map. Help us do it. Please dig deep, it's the right thing to do. Thanks, Anthony.

story:
My Your Our Water 

My Your Our Water began as a collaborative project with Scottsdale Public Art and Salt River Project focused on the water issues specific to the desert of Arizona but it quickly grew into a grassroots conversation about local, regional and global water issues. My Your Our Water is a multiplatform project of intersection, connectivity & aesthetics that revolves around water. There are four components to the project, A Tricked-Out-Tricycle, A Blog,  A Community Facebook Page and a Floating Illuminated Sign.

The Trike was designed to be ridden along the 131 miles of canal paths that line the working canal system in the greater Phoenix, Arizona. During these canal rides, I engage other trail users in conversation about water: water ways, watersheds, water delivery systems, water quality, water resources, water recreation, water conservation, local water issues, national water issues and global water issues. Individuals are invited to participate in the project by submitting imagery of Water in their lives. 

The Blog My Your Our Water  has a daily blog that began in conjunction with the Tricycle rides.The blog is a combination of water facts, documentation of canal rides, interactions and imagery submitted by participants.

The Facebook Page

The Facebook page is an outlet to connect interested individuals with timely articles about current and news breaking water issues, petitions and calls to action. This page creates an easy forum for My Your Our Water community to share information and spark change.

The Illuminated Sign is the third component of MYOW. It is 45ft LED illuminated aluminum sign that reads MY YOUR OUR. The sign was launched in the Arizona Canal on the Scottsdale Waterfront in February of 2015. Each aluminum channel letter is 5ft tall, blue aluminum with an acrylic face. 

My Your Our Water  has both a personal and global relevance. The goal is to ramp up the project to have a greater component of activism and national relevance.The more individuals involved in a conversation about any aspect of water: drought, conservation, plastics, clean drinking resources, impacts of farming, recreation, industry, recycled water, whatever the aspect of water- the more individuals participating in the conversation the more likely for an actual shift in thinking to occur and policy changes to be enacted.

My Your Our Water goes to the Midwest

My Your Our Water is ready to hit the river. The Grand River in Grand Rapids, Michigan to be exact. The project needs help getting from Arizona to Michigan. Your support will help cover the cost of shipping, installation, and insurance for both the sign and the tricycle while defraying the costs of basic structural changes needed to place the sign in a natural flowing river. Did you know that the Grand River is the longest river in Michigan at 252 miles, emptying into Lake Michigan ? Did you know that 21% of the world's fresh water supply is located in the the Great Lakes?  Did you know that 84% of the fresh water in the United States is located in the Great Lakes ? Did you know that  4 of the 5 Great Lakes touch the state of Michigan? Lake Superior, Laker Huron, Lake Michigan and Lake Erie are all directly impacted by what happens in Michigan. My Water. Your Water. Our Water.

Your Impact

This is your chance to help start a conversation about the most critical resource to all life on the planet. Your generous support will help this project expand and gain national attention. Hopefully, this attention will help grow the conversation about water in our lives and how it inextricably links us all.

Challenges

It's difficult to take action. It's difficult to make a difference but My Your Our Water would like to try by continuing to initiate conversation about Water and its intimate connection to all living organisms. With your help, maybe we can make the conversation heard.

Other Ways You Can Help

go to www.changethecourse.org and www.5gyres.org  and take action

send your own images of water to MyYourOurWater@gmail.com

FOLLOW the blog at http://.myyourourwater.blogspot.com/

LIKE us on Facebook https://www.facebook.com/MyYourOurWater

VISIT the website http://www.myyourourwater.com/

Share with your friends!

My Your Our Water 

My Your Our Water began as a collaborative project with Scottsdale Public Art and Salt River Project focused on the water issues specific to the desert of Arizona but it quickly grew into a grassroots conversation about local, regional and global water issues. My Your Our Water is a multiplatform project of intersection, connectivity & aesthetics that revolves around water. There are four components to the project, A Tricked-Out-Tricycle, A Blog,  A Community Facebook Page and a Floating Illuminated Sign.
The Trike was designed to be ridden along the 131 miles of canal paths that line the working canal system in the greater Phoenix, Arizona. During these canal rides, I engage other trail users in conversation about water: water ways, watersheds, water delivery systems, water quality, water resources, water recreation, water conservation, local water issues, national water issues and global water issues. Individuals are invited to participate in the project by submitting imagery of Water in their lives. 
The Blog My Your Our Water  has a daily blog that began in conjunction with the Tricycle rides.The blog is a combination of water facts, documentation of canal rides, interactions and imagery submitted by participants.

story:
Short Summary

I am Miles Eastman, I have been in charge of getting the God booth to the playa for the past 4 years. I started coming to Burning Man in 2005 with OBOP the camp that created the TALK TO GOD phone booth. (Drawings of the new booth design coming very soon)

The TALK TO GOD phone booth is an interactive instalation that has touched the hearts, minds and souls thousands over its 14 year history.  This simple two way phone line a phone booth a God throne about 100+ft away, facilitates two strangers the chance to have some of the most intimate and profound conversations of their burn and their lives.  There is the right god for you on the other end of the line every time.

As it is now we are tied to a diesel generator for power and have to dig a trench to lay our power and phone cables.  This dramatically limits our ability for placement on the playa and our ability to install it at other events where we can not dig a 150ft trench across the event grounds.  

The GOD BOOTH 2.0 

Help us go solar and wireless with a new booth that is lighter,  brighter and more durable booth. Making build and strike much faster, and the booth will live indefinitely.  With LED backlit signage, upgraded mic's in the hand sets for clearer sound quality.  And don't forget the laser light pointing into the heavens, it comes on when you pick up the phone and make the connection to GOD.

What We Need 

  • $1,900.00 IN BUILDING MATERIALS FOR THE NEW BOOTH.  We are going to do a round booth with backlit plexiglass floor, a printed backlit fish eye print of the heavens on top. Rolled steel structure with modular design for easy set up.
  • $700.00 ELECTRONIC COMPONENTS FOR WIRELESS SYSTEM. Two wireless routers and components, LED lighting, Upgraded microphones for both phones, phone line simulator, better digital recording device,  audio editing and promotions, webpage development and public promotions, speakers for the god throne area and misc connectors cables and switches. 
  • $2,000.00 SOLAR SYSTEM AND BATTERIES.  Two separate solar systems. two 300w panels, two battery banks, two charge controllers, cables, enclosed batterie/electrical box with panel mounts. 
  •  $300.00 Storage  
  • $4,900.00 TOTAL 

What You Get.  Perks Offered

  • God Phone stickers with every contribution.
  • Your choice of Silver or Bronze Burning man Pendants designed by Miles Eastman 
  • Your choice of Silver or Bronze God Booth pendant designed by Miles Eastman
  • Your very own framed  TALK TO GOD sign. I am very excited about this light box backlit with LEDs.

The Impact

With these changes we are frees to bring TALK TO GOD booth off playa.  It opens up the ability to install it at other festivals and events regardless of the environment or power limitations.  

  • Taking TALK TO GOD off playa and sharing its magic to thousands more people  every year is a major motivator to do these upgrades. City streets, festivals, parties and any event anywhere are now accessible.  
  • Audio recording of selected conversations will be available and shared for spiritual and enlightening purposes. So many of the conversations are powerful and profound.  We are developing ways to share these with a wider audience.  
  • The GOD phone has become an icon on the playa over the years, and with your help we can share this powerful instillation for connection and personal interaction that breaks down social, and spiritual boundaries.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Please contact us if you would like to help in other ways. If you have skills in electronics, web design, audio.  If your a DJ looking for sound clips.  We are open to collaborations of many kinds.
  • Please share our link with others that you think will like to hear about our project.

story:
Yego Arts is a fine arts studio in Kigali which currently has ten well-established painters as its members. Its mission is to create a vibrant self-sustaining community of established visual artists in Rwanda, and to create new avenues for Rwandans to use art as a means of healing and generating sustainable livelihoods for themselves and their families. The studio was founded in 2012 by Tony Cyizanye using money earned from the sale of his own paintings. He organized a group of local artists and community members to remodel an unfinished building in the Nyarutarama neighborhood of Kigali into a professional art studio.

On August 20, 2015, contractors came to the center legally rented by Yego Arts and ordered that everything be removed within 15 minutes. They explained only that the land had been sold, and the buildings were to be immediately demolished. While the artists were scrambling to collect their belongings, workers began to tear down their buildings. Artwork was destroyed. The community is shocked and saddened by this event, but Yego Arts is determined to move forward. They have already located a potential new site in the Kigali neighborhood of Remera, but lack the necessary funds to rent and renovate the space. 

Before this tragic event, Yego Arts regularly held cultural events such as gallery exhibitions, dance performances, painting workshops, and concerts. It was also a place for cultural exchange, frequently welcoming visitors from around the world. The artists are also active in the larger community, regularly running "Live Painting" events in Kigali restaurants, hotels, and hostels. At these events, spectators can engage with the artists and watch their painting process while enjoying live music.

The artists would like to show their appreciation for your generous support! If you donate at least $200, you will receive a painting. If you are not able to support them financially, but believe in their cause, please share this campaign.

Short Summary

  • An artist collective founded by Tony Cyizanye in 2012 lost its home base.
  • The collective hosted many cultural events, including gallery exhibitions, dance performances, painting workshops, and concerts. Without a center, these events can no longer happen.
  • Your donation helps Yego Arts to rent and renovate a suitable space to continue the work they do to enrich their community.

story:
Learn, See, and Experience:

The arts are a vital part of any community. The House of MAGIC Foundation for the Arts is a 501(c)3 charitable organization helping to improve lives through a variety of arts programs. Our mission is to support the arts through the hearts of the community by providing an outlet for individuals to learn, see, experience, and achieve art in all its forms. No one is turned away from our programs regardless of race, creed, or financial hardship. We believe the arts help improve grades, reduce crime, strengthen communities, and improve the overall development of an individual. More and more the arts are being stripped from our educational system, making organizations like ours vital to building stronger communities.

The House of MAGIC Foundation for the Arts provides a location for individuals to share and teach in a variety of art forms, giving people of all ages a place to learn and grow. Art inspires art. 

Our Accomplishments:

We have just completed renovations to our new facility, which houses the various programs offered at The House of MAGIC Foundation for the Arts. With your generous donation, you will help ensure that we can continue to provide the programs necessary to help keep the arts alive in our community and for personal development.

Even though we are new to the community, we have already begun to see an impact from the programs we offer:

  • We helped a little boy who suffered from a learning disability and had a difficult time with speech, get up on stage and perform some amazing feats of magic in front of his school audience. He was a big hit, it brought tears of joy to the mother (and to us), and it gave him a huge boost in confidence. 
  • We took a student who had a hard time focusing in school and had poor grades, and taught him classical guitar. He became more focused, more confident; and his grades improved as a result.
  • We gave an instructor a place to share his skills with other individuals when no one else would give him the opportunity.
  • We provide a platform for individuals to perform the trade they have learned.
  • We offer programs to the community, often free of charge, to help businesses advance, to help individuals overcome their challenges, and a platform for people to express themselves freely and without judgement.  

Give a little: Receive a little:

    • For your $1 donation, you'll receive an email from our Board of Directors with a poem written by one of our founders.
    • For your $5 donation, you'll receive a private video link to a few simple magic tricks you can do at home.
    • For your $25 donation, you'll receive a limited-edition deck of playing cards.
    • For your $50 donation, you'll receive the official House of MAGIC Foundation for the Arts t-shirt and a book containing 50 easy magic tricks.
    • For your $100 donation, your name will be placed on our Build-a-Foundation Wall of Fame with a certificate of support and the official House of MAGIC Foundation for the Arts t-shirt.
    • For your $500 donation, you'll receive a 1-year pass to all showcases presented at The House of MAGIC Foundation for the Arts and two House of MAGIC wine glasses. You will also receive a plaque, with your name, at the door of our theater and a certificate of support, showing that you helped open doors for the arts.
    • For your $1,000 donation, you will receive all the above.
